The Cell Phone and Brain Cancer Myth

13 Wednesday Oct 2010

Posted by Kyle Hill in Physics, Science Myths, Science News

≈ 6 Comments

Tags

brain cancer, cell phone radiation, cell phones, cell phones and tumors, pseudoscience, science, skeptic

AT&Tumor?

There has been a lot of fear over the years of the potential risks from prolonged cell phone use. Aside from “cell-phone elbow” and increased ear bacteria, brain tumors are the most worrying of the supposed risks. This fear has been around ever since cell phones became publicly available, and the trend continues as your cell has basically become an extension of your own head.

However, as we will discuss below, all of the research concerning cell phones and brain cancer has not shown any risks to your health. Furthermore, a look at the general physics will explain how cell phones simply cannot cause cancer.

Let’s look at the evidence.

Dropping Fears, Not Calls

On the extreme side there are people campaigning for the abolition of cell phones, wi-fi, and cable; on the lighter side there are parents who refuse to let their children use cell phones for any extended period. Where do these groups get their fear of cell phones from? Can we use our common sense to decide that since cell phones output radiation, it must be bad for us? I believe that this is a case where our common sense is no match for the high-powered electron microscope of science.

I have heard a lot of things about the risks of cell phone use, and most of it is drawn from the fact that cell phones output electromagnetic radiation. That right there is a phrase that creates half of the old-wives tales that you will hear about cell phones. When most people hear “radiation”, they think of something akin to chemotherapy or the atomic bomb, without realizing that radiation is just a term that explains how energy is transferred in wave-form. This knee-jerk negative reaction will allow people to continue thinking that cell phones cause cancer, chalking it up to plain common sense.

But just what kindof radiation do cell phones output? How much energy is contained in the radiation? These are all questions answered in physics.

Amplitudes and Frequencies (Not the hippie kind)

Let’s get an idea of where cell phone output lies in the electromagnetic spectrum:

Cell phones emit radiation in the form of RF (radio-frequency) energy, which puts it at the far left of the above chart. Why is it the case that this band of radiation cannot cause cancer? The answer is in the amount of energy contained in these RF waves.

Cell phones cannot cause cancer, because they do not emit enough energy to break the molecular bonds inside cells (which can cause cancer). Some forms of electromagnetic radiation, such as x-rays, gamma rays and ultraviolet (UV) radiation, are energetic enough to break the bonds in key molecules such as DNA and thereby generate mutations that lead to cancer. Electromagnetic radiation in the form of infrared light, microwaves, television and radio signals, and AC power is too weak to break those bonds, so that’s why we don’t worry about radios, televisions, microwave ovens and power outlets causing cancer.

Known carcinogens such as x-rays, gamma rays and UV rays have energies greater than 480 kilojoules per mole (kJ/mole), which is enough to break chemical bonds. Green-light photons hold 240 kJ/mole of energy, which is enough to bend (but not break) the rhodopsin molecules in our retinas that trigger our photosensitive rod cells to fire. A cell phone generates radiation of less than 0.001 kJ/mole. That is 480,000 times weaker than UV rays and 240,000 times weaker than green light!

Even making the cell phone ra­di­a­tion more intense just means that there are more photons of that energy, not stronger photons. Cell phone photons cannot add up to become UV photons or have their effect any more than microwave or radio-wave photons can. In fact, if the bonds holding the key mole­cules of life together could be broken at the energy levels of cell phones, there would be no life at all because the various natural sources of energy (radiation) from the environment would prevent such bonds from ever forming in the first place.

The Medicine

Although there have been mixed results, none overtly positive or negative, recent reviews of the largest sets of data show that there is no link between cell phone use and the incidence of brain tumors. Although none of these studies is the definitive smoking gun, it gives us just enough breathing room to realize that these unfounded claims are in reflection of the physics explained above.

Studies of the effects of exposure from 20 or more years still need to be done (because cell phones have not existed for that long), but so far, in this case, one can say it is impossible for cell phones to hurt the brain—with the exception, of course, of hitting someone on the head with one.
